head.title: Spiral Turbulence: From the Oxidation of CO on Pt(110) to Ventricular Fibrillation

article.h1: Spiral Turbulence: From the Oxidation of CO on Pt(110) to Ventricular Fibrillation

span.span:
Sitabhra Sinha1,212FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{1,2} and Rahul Pandit1,212FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{1,2}
11FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{1}Department of Physics

India
22FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 FLOATSUPERSCRIPT:end{}^{2}Jawaharlal Nehru Centre for Advanced Scientific Research

div.p: We give a brief overview of systems that show spiral patterns and spatiotemporally chaotic states. We concentrate on two physical systems: (1) the oxidation of CO on Pt(110) and (2) ventricular fibrillation in hearts. The equations that have been suggested as simple models for these two different systems are closely related for they are both excitable media. We present these equations and give a short summary of the phenomena they yield.

Spiral waves are found in a wide variety of physical, chemical, and biological systems. These include convection patterns in cylindrical cells [1], patterns in the Belousov-Zhabotinsky chemical reactions [1, 2], the oscillations of cyclic-AMP in aggregating Dictyostelium Discoidium amoebae [1, 3], the oxidation of carbon monoxide (CO) on surfaces of platinum single crystals [4], calcium waves in the cell cytoplasm [5] of Xenophus oocytes, and in ventricular fibrillation [6] which is perhaps the most dangerous form of cardiac arrhythmia. A variety of mathematical models have been used to describe these phenomena; we refer the reader to the review by Cross and Hohenberg for a recent discussion of many such models [1]. The models range from cellular automata [7] to deterministic partial differential equations, such as the Complex Ginzburg Landau equation (for oscillatory chemical reactions near onset) and equations in the FitzHugh-Nagumo class (for CO oxidation and ventricular fibrillation). We concentrate on the FitzHugh-Nagumo types of equations here. Our description is not very technical since the talk on which this article is based was aimed at an audience comprising scientists from different disciplines. We begin with a brief overview of phenomena followed by an introduction to equations in the FitzHugh-Nagumo class. We then present some results for the specific models suggested for the oxidation of CO on Pt(110) and ventricular fibrillation [4, 8] including our recent studies [11].

Many chemical reactions display spontaneous spatial self-organisation if the reactors are not stirred and the reactants are fed at a constant rate. Among these reactions the oxidation of CO on Pt(110) has been studied in great detail [4]. The experimental setup consists of a cell containing a Pt wafer kept at a constant temperature. The reactants are fed into the cell at a constant rate and the products removed. Spatial structures in the concentration fields of the reactants have been observed by using photoelectron emission microscopy (PEEM). For a picture of the growth of a spiral wave on such a Pt(110) wafer see Ref. [4].

A human heart consists of four chambers - the two upper atria and two lower ventricles. Heart activity is driven by periodic signals emitted by the cells of the sinus node situated in the upper right atrium. These cells initiate the heartbeat cycle by emitting a pulse of electrical activity. This activity travels as a wave across the atria and stimulates the nerves of the atrioventricular node (AVN). From the AVN the signal travels along the His bundle and into the ventricles via the Purkinje fibre network which extensively innervates the ventricular wall. The ventricles now contract thus completing the beat cycle. Cardiac arrhythmia is caused when the signal from the sinus node does not propagate in the normal manner. Especially dangerous is ventricular fibrillation, an irregular pulsation of the ventricles, which is a major cause of death in the industrialised world [12]. It has been conjectured for many years [13] that ventricular fibrillation is associated with the formation of spiral waves (or their three-dimensional analogues called scroll waves) on the walls of the ventricles. Experimental evidence for such spiral waves has been increasing with the advent of voltage-sensitive dyes and advanced imaging techniques [14]. Figure 2 shows such a spiral wave on the ventricle of a canine heart. Such spirals have also been seen to break up.

figure.figcaption: Figure 1: A spiral wave on a canine heart imaged using voltage-sensitive dyes and CCD cameras, after Ref. [14] . Image obtained from and reproduced with the permission of W. Ditto.

div.p: Both the oxidation of CO on Pt (110) and ventricular fibrillation have been the focus of many theoretical studies. These are motivated partially by a desire to understand the phenomena seen in experiments and partially to elucidate the general properties of systems displaying such spatiotemporally chaotic, statistical steady states. The remainder of this paper is organised as follows: Section 2 consists of an introduction to FitzHugh-Nagumo equations and the models we consider. Section 3 describes some results for the model of CO oxidation on Pt(110). Section 4 describes some results for the model of ventricular fibrillation. Section 5 ends with concluding remarks.
FitzHugh-Nagumo-type equations belong to the general class of reaction-diffusion equations. These are of the form

The Panfilov-Hogeweg model for ventricular fibrillation that we consider is [8]

Physically Ïµâ¢(e,g)-1italic-Ïµsuperscriptğ‘’ğ‘”1italic-epsilon OPEN:( italic-e PUNCT:, italic-g CLOSE:) POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\epsilon(e,g)^{-1} determines the refractory time period of this model of ventricular muscle. Since the ventricles are electrically insulated from the atria, we impose Neumann boundary conditions.

For the model of CO oxidation on Pt(110) (2), Hildebrand et. al. [4], find that there are many different statistical steady states. These include states with no waves (N), states with flat shrinking waves (F), states with rigidly rotating spirals (S), states with meandering spirals (M) and turbulent states with creation and annihilation of spirals (T1 and T2). These authors have found a stability diagram or â€phase diagramâ€ in the b-Îµğ‘ğœ€italic-b ADDOP:minus italic-varepsilonb-\varepsilon plane for a=0.84ğ‘0.84italic-a RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.84a=0.84, and have calculated the spatial autocorrelation function of the density of spiral cores âŸ¨nâ¢(xâ†’,t)â¢nâ¢(xâ†’+sâ†’,t+Ï„)âŸ©delimited-âŸ¨âŸ©ğ‘›â†’ğ‘¥ğ‘¡ğ‘›â†’ğ‘¥â†’ğ‘ ğ‘¡ğœOPEN:langle italic-n OPEN:( OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-x ARG:end PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) italic-n OPEN:( OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-x ARG:end ADDOP:plus OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-s ARG:end PUNCT:, italic-t ADDOP:plus italic-tau CLOSE:) CLOSE:rangle\langle n(\vec{x},t)n(\vec{x}+\vec{s},t+\tau)\rangle\/. They suggest that the change in the spiral dynamics on passing from T1 to T2 is like a â€liquid-gasâ€ transition. We have simulated model (2) by discretising it on a square lattice and using a variable stepsize fourth-fifth order Runge-Kutta integrator for time stepping [9]. In some cases we also use a fast integration scheme proposed by Barkley [10]. We have used Neumann boundary conditions to compare with model (3). We have investigated the local dynamics, i.e., the dynamics obtained by plotting uâ¢(xnâ†’,tn)ğ‘¢â†’subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›italic-u OPEN:( OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end PUNCT:, italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)u(\vec{x_{n}},t_{n}) versus vâ¢(xnâ†’,tn),n=1,2,â€¦formulae-sequenceğ‘£â†’subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›ğ‘›12â€¦italic-v OPEN:( OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end PUNCT:, italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) PUNCT:, italic-n RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, NUMBER:2 PUNCT:, ID:ldotsv(\vec{x_{n}},t_{n}),n=1,2,\ldots for fixed spatial location xnâ†’â†’subscriptğ‘¥ğ‘›OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end ARG:end\vec{x_{n}} and tn=nâ¢Î”subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›ğ‘›Î”italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals italic-n Deltat_{n}=n\Delta where Î”Î”Delta\Delta is a sampling interval which we choose to be =0.1absent0.1RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.1=0.1 time units. Such local phase portraits show that, in the states S, M, and T1, the system displays oscillatory behaviour; a representative phase portrait is shown in Fig. (2) for T1.

figure.figcaption: Figure 2: The local phase portrait in the state T1 of model (2) at Îµ=0.0781ğœ€0.0781italic-varepsilon RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.0781\varepsilon=0.0781. Such local phase portraits get progressively more disordered in the regimes M, T1 and T2.

We define the phase Ï•â¢(ğ±,t)â‰¡tan-1â¡((vâ¢(ğ±,t)-vâˆ—)/(uâ¢(ğ±,t)-uâˆ—))italic-Ï•ğ±ğ‘¡superscript1ğ‘£ğ±ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘£âˆ—ğ‘¢ğ±ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¢âˆ—italic-phi OPEN:( bold-x PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equivalent-to TRIGFUNCTION:tangent POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end OPEN:( OPEN:( italic-v OPEN:( bold-x PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) ADDOP:minus italic-v POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:ast POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) MULOP:divide OPEN:( italic-u OPEN:( bold-x PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) ADDOP:minus italic-u POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:ast POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:) CLOSE:)\phi({\bf{x}},t)\equiv\tan^{-1}((v({\bf{x}},t)-v_{\ast})/(u({\bf{x}},t)-u_{% \ast}))\/ and note that it winds by 2â¢Ï€2ğœ‹NUMBER:2 italic-pi2\pi\/ around the cores of spiral defects [4]. Thus it can be used to obtain the defect density ÏğœŒitalic-rho\rho [11].

figure.figcaption: Figure 3: A plot of uâ¢(xâ†’)ğ‘¢â†’ğ‘¥italic-u OPEN:( OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-x ARG:end CLOSE:)u(\vec{x}) as a function of space in model (2). The colour at a point is proportional to the value of uğ‘¢italic-uu\/ at that point, obtained after evolving a typical initial condition for 5000 time units . Note the similarity of this figure with Fig (5). For this figure Îµ=0.073ğœ€0.073italic-varepsilon RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.073\varepsilon=0.073 which corresponds to the T1 state.

Figure 4: The phase Ï•italic-Ï•italic-phi\phi\/ (see text) corresponding to the field configuration of Fig. (3) as a function of space. The colour at a point is proportional to the value of the phase at that point.

div.p: It is believed that ventricular fibrillation occurs because of the spontaneous breakdown of contraction waves in the heart muscle leading to a state with many rotating spirals [13, 14]. Physiological abnormalities do not seem to play an important role in this arrhythmia in a sizeable fraction of cases. Thus it is interesting to study models in which spiral breakup appears spontaneously without introducing spatial inhomogenieties in the diffusion constant, for example. For the model (3), Panfilov et. al. [8] find that, for the parameter values e1=0.0026,e2=0.837,C1=20,C2=3,C3=15,a=0.06,k=3,Ïµ1-1=75,Ïµ2-1=1,g1=1.8formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘’10.0026formulae-sequencesubscriptğ‘’20.837formulae-sequencesubscriptğ¶120formulae-sequencesubscriptğ¶23formulae-sequencesubscriptğ¶315formulae-sequenceğ‘0.06formulae-sequenceğ‘˜3formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptitalic-Ïµ1175formulae-sequencesuperscriptsubscriptitalic-Ïµ211subscriptğ‘”11.8italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.0026 PUNCT:, italic-e POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.837 PUNCT:, italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:20 PUNCT:, italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:3 PUNCT:, italic-C POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:15 PUNCT:, italic-a RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.06 PUNCT:, italic-k RELOP:equals NUMBER:3 PUNCT:, italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:75 PUNCT:, italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1 PUNCT:, italic-g POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:1 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:equals NUMBER:1.8e_{1}=0.0026,e_{2}=0.837,C_{1}=20,C_{2}=3,C_{3}=15,a=0.06,k=3,{\epsilon_{1}}^{% -1}=75,{\epsilon_{2}}^{-1}=1,g_{1}=1.8 and 0.5<Ïµ3-1<100.5superscriptsubscriptitalic-Ïµ3110NUMBER:0.5 RELOP:less-than italic-epsilon POSTSUBSCRIPT:start NUMBER:3 POSTSUBSCRIPT:end POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start ADDOP:minus NUMBER:1 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end RELOP:less-than NUMBER:100.5<{\epsilon_{3}}^{-1}<10, an initial condition in the shape of a broken wave gives rise to states containing many spirals. They have also calculated an electrocardiogram (ECG) numerically for this model in the turbulent state. In this section we elucidate the spatiotemporal nature of the chaotic behaviour of this system. In Ref. [8] it has been noted that the breakdown of spirals in models (2) and (3) is qualitatively similar. We elaborate on this similarity below. The state with broken spirals in model (3) is similar to the state T1 in model (2) as can be seen by comparing Figs. (5) and (3).

figure.figcaption: Figure 5: The configuration of the eğ‘’italic-ee\/ field of model (3) on a system of size 256Ã—256256256NUMBER:256 MULOP:times NUMBER:256256\times 256 obtained after evolving a typical initial condition for 1000 time units.

div.p: We have simulated model (3) using finite-differencing in space with a forward euler algorithm for time stepping. Most of our simulations are done with a system size of 256Ã—256256256NUMBER:256 MULOP:times NUMBER:256256\times 256 with a spatial grid step of dâ¢x=0.5ğ‘‘ğ‘¥0.5italic-d italic-x RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.5dx=0.5 and a time step of dâ¢t=0.022ğ‘‘ğ‘¡0.022italic-d italic-t RELOP:equals NUMBER:0.022dt=0.022. Physically, one time unit is equal to 5 milliseconds, while one spatial unit is equal to 1 millimeter. We use the parameter values given above. We have calculated a local phase portrait for this model, i.e. a plot of eâ¢(xâ†’n,tn)ğ‘’subscriptâ†’ğ‘¥ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›italic-e OPEN:( OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-x ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)e(\vec{x}_{n},t_{n}) vs gâ¢(xâ†’n,tn)ğ‘”subscriptâ†’ğ‘¥ğ‘›subscriptğ‘¡ğ‘›italic-g OPEN:( OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-x ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)g(\vec{x}_{n},t_{n}) for a fixed spatial location xâ†’nsubscriptâ†’ğ‘¥ğ‘›OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-x ARG:end POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-n POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\vec{x}_{n}. This is shown in Fig. (6). Note that this local phase portrait is similar to that in the T1 state of the CO oxidation model (2).

figure.figcaption: Figure 6: The upper figure shows a local phase portrait of the model (3); the lower shows a time series of the transmembrane potential eğ‘’italic-ee\/. The system size was 256Ã—256256256NUMBER:256 MULOP:times NUMBER:256256\times 256 with a grid spacing of 0.50.5NUMBER:0.50.5.

div.p: We find that for a system of size 50Ã—505050NUMBER:50 MULOP:times NUMBER:5050\times 50 the lifetime Ï„tsubscriptğœğ‘¡italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\tau_{t} of the turbulent state is âˆ¼300similar-toabsent300RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:300\sim 300 time units. After this time the entire field configuration goes to zero for various initial conditions. For a system of size 100Ã—100100100NUMBER:100 MULOP:times NUMBER:100100\times 100 Ï„tâˆ¼950similar-tosubscriptğœğ‘¡950italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:end RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:950\tau_{t}\sim 950 time units. We conjecture that Ï„tsubscriptğœğ‘¡italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\tau_{t} grows with system size; we are investigating this scaling of Ï„tsubscriptğœğ‘¡italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\tau_{t}. The typical size of a human heart corresponds to a system size of âˆ¼600Ã—600similar-toabsent600600RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:600 MULOP:times NUMBER:600\sim 600\times 600 so the size dependence of Ï„tsubscriptğœğ‘¡italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\tau_{t} is of obvious interest. We note in passing that this qualitative trend of Ï„tsubscriptğœğ‘¡italic-tau POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-t POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\tau_{t} increasing with system size is in accord with the well-known phenomenon that only the larger mammals have heart attacks.

To characterise chaos in model (3), we have calculated the maximum Lyapunov exponent Î»mâ¢aâ¢xsubscriptğœ†ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\lambda_{max} for a system of size 128Ã—128128128NUMBER:128 MULOP:times NUMBER:128128\times 128. The maximum Lyapunov exponent measures the divergence of nearby trajectories in the system. To calculate it we use standard methods [15]. In the transient turbulent state of model (3), Î»mâ¢aâ¢xsubscriptğœ†ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\lambda_{max} saturates to a value of âˆ¼0.2similar-toabsent0.2RELOP:similar-to NUMBER:0.2\sim 0.2. This is shown in Fig (7). Note that when this transient decays, the maximum Lyapunov Exponent decreases to negative values.

figure.figcaption: Figure 7: The approximation to the maximum Lyapunov exponent Î»mâ¢aâ¢xsubscriptğœ†ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\lambda_{max}\/ at time tğ‘¡italic-tt\/ versus tğ‘¡italic-tt\/. Note that Î»mâ¢aâ¢xsubscriptğœ†ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\lambda_{max}\/ approaches a positive constant (â‰ƒ0.2similar-to-or-equalsabsent0.2RELOP:similar-to-or-equals NUMBER:0.2\simeq 0.2\/) and then decays at large times to negative values. This occurs because there is a long-lived chaotic transient which finally decays to a state that is constant in space with eâ¢(xâ†’,t)=0ğ‘’â†’ğ‘¥ğ‘¡0italic-e OPEN:( OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-x ARG:end PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals NUMBER:0e(\vec{x},t)=0 and gâ¢(xâ†’,t)=0ğ‘”â†’ğ‘¥ğ‘¡0italic-g OPEN:( OVERACCENT:vec ARG:start italic-x ARG:end PUNCT:, italic-t CLOSE:) RELOP:equals NUMBER:0g(\vec{x},t)=0 everywhere. The lifetime of this chaotic transient increases with the size of the system (see text).

div.p: Spiral patterns are seen in a wide variety of natural systems [1]. Here we have concentrated on two such systems which are also excitable media. The chaotic states of these systems display the breakup of large spirals into smaller ones in the states T1 and T2. The qualitative similarity of such spiral breakup in models (2) and (3) has been mentioned briefly earlier [8]. Here we have elucidated this similarity by comparing the spiral patterns (Figs. 3 and 5) in the state T1 of model (2) and the chaotic state of model (3); local phase portraits (Figs. 2 and 6) are also similar. We have characterised the chaos in model (3) by computing the maximum Lyapunov exponent Î»mâ¢aâ¢xsubscriptğœ†ğ‘šğ‘ğ‘¥italic-lambda POSTSUBSCRIPT:start italic-m italic-a italic-x POSTSUBSCRIPT:end\lambda_{max}\/ (Fig. 7) as we have done for model (2) elsewhere [16].

Our study shows that there is considerable similarity between the behaviour of model (2) in the state T1 and model (3) for the parameter values given above. It should be possible to exploit this similarity to gain new insights about these two excitable media (e.g., by doing experiments on the oxidation of CO on Pt(110) which might be hard to do on a human heart). Of course some caution must be exercised while doing this for the two models are different in some respects: the chaotic state of model (3) is a transient for the system sizes we have studied, whereas the analogous state for model (2) seems to be a statistical steady state; furthermore, if the âˆ‡2superscriptâˆ‡2OPERATOR:nabla POSTSUPERSCRIPT:start NUMBER:2 POSTSUPERSCRIPT:end\nabla^{2}\/ terms are dropped in both models, then model (2) has an extra unstable fixed point [at (u,v)=(u*,v*)ğ‘¢ğ‘£subscriptğ‘¢subscriptğ‘£OPEN:( italic-u PUNCT:, italic-v CLOSE:) RELOP:equals OPEN:( italic-u POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUBSCRIPT:end PUNCT:, italic-v POSTSUBSCRIPT:start MULOP:times POSTSUBSCRIPT:end CLOSE:)(u,v)=(u_{*},v_{*})\/], i.e., the reaction kinetics are different in the two models. We hope our work will stimulate experimental studies that will try to elucidate the similarities and differences between spiral turbulence in the oxidation of CO on Pt(110) and ventricular fibrillation. Since ventricular fibrillation in cardiac muscle is fatal [13, 6, 12], any insight gained about it by studying similar systems is of great interest.
We thank CSIR and JNCASR for support and SERC (IISc) for computational facilities.

D. Barkley, Physica D, 49, (1991); M. Doule et. al., Int. J. Bifurcation and Chaos, 7, 11, (1997).
A. Pande and R. Pandit in Structure and Dynamics of Materials in the Mesoscopic Domain, eds. B.D. Kulkarni and Moti Lal, Imperial College Press â€“ The Royal Society (in press).
A.T. Winfree, When Time breaks Down (Princeton University Press, Princeton, 1987).
F.X. Witkowski et. al., Nature, 392, 78, (1998); R. A. Gray et. al. ibid, 75, (1998).
T. Parker and L. Chua, Practical Numerical Algorithms for Chaotic Systems (Springer, Berlin,1989).
A. Pande and R. Pandit, to be published.
